comments.commentBody:
Obama didn't need to plant any leaks to "sabotage" Trump's presidency -- Trump is doing that all on his own...plus, there's evidence!
If anything, former President Obama has provided this country with a view into everthing Trump is doing his utmost to cover up.
We owe him a debt of thanks for that.

Plennie,

The ballistic missile subs of the old CCCP had several levels of political officers on board. They were armed and in the "launch loop". While the Officers and crews were very brave to even go to sea in those subs, they were not stupid. There was no order given to launch anything on either side.

A central fact that the North Korean leadership knows full well is that hours after launching an attack they all would be dead -- as would their families.  For that very reason a preemptive attack on North Korean leadership will leave behind generals and colonels who will be more inclined to accept the new reality rather than follow Kim into the grave. Of course that is terribly risky.  As has been the irresponsible policy of wait and see, which has allowed this menace to develop over twenty years.  And perhaps even more risky is doing next to nothing, while North Korea to moves forward, until we are completely at the mercy of the tantrums of the virulent infant who runs the country.
We launch a missile. They know it's coming so they launch theirs since they have nothing to lose. Bingo. Armageddon!

"until we are completely at the mercy of the tantrums of the virulent infant who runs the country."
Sound like North Korea and America have at least one thing in common.
Who is the "virulent infant" to whom you refer?  Kim is looking pretty coolheaded.  But only relatively.

Just as we should be promoting the reunification of North and South Korea, we should also be seriously considering, for numerous highly worthwhile reasons, going beyond NAFTA to the actual merging of the USA and Mexico into one nation.

While Canadians don't seem to have nearly as great a desire to emigrate to the US as Mexicans, it's obvious that tens of millions of Mexicans do, and have done so, in an effort to improve their lives. As citizens of the US, they have experienced improvement in their lives. Even those who are not yet citizens have seen improvement, for which they are highly grateful.

While this is not the place for a discussion on merging Mexico and the US, the time is certainly right, both from a strategic perspective, and from an economic perspective. All the same reasons to merge two large corporations apply to the concept of merging two such similar, contiguous nations. The cost savings and strengthening of the resulting nation would be stupendous, and beneficial to every single resident from Augusta, ME to Cancun.

Agree, Trump is simply not on the same plane as many world leaders, worse yet is the fact that he has brought in a cabinet who is far less skilled than he is, if that is even possible

The EPA thing is driving me crazy, Mr Pruitt is concerned with only one thing, money.....the air, water matter zero, simply money that's it

North Korea would be a problem for a competent president and WH staff. Trump and company are not competent. Rather, they are as dangerous as Kim Jong-un and that regime.

The other stories on today's front page depict a very scary scene. Trump is feeling "beseiged" by the Russian/Sessions' scandal. Trump views military power as "raw" and a "means to an end". Trump has now charged that Obama tapped his phones.

Trump is unfit to be president. This is not about partisanship. This is about Trump's sanity and our safety. I hope the Republicans still have statesmen who will put country over party. Someone urgently needs to approach VP Pence and explain how to invoke the 25th Amendment. Every minute Pence delays is a minute Americans live in peril.
And Trump calls the free press the enemy of the American people.  I'd say North Korea and Russia top my list.

FYI. Several levels of editing are involved before any material that might be deemed sensitive goes to print.
You should instead be worrying about what has been revealed by the revolving door policy of Donald Trump, when it comes to Russia and this country's National Security.
Yes. Trump "inherits" a problem he would've known more about, had he not skipped so many National Security briefings.

"Trump Inherits a Secret Cyberwar Against North Korean Missiles."

A rather odd headline, don't you think? An article about North Korea's escalating conceal and carry doomsday ambition and US covert efforts to thwart them is framed not as a profound existential threat to humanity but as Execdrin Headache #28, which Obama left for Trump to clean up.

So the story isn't North Korea playing liar's dice with nuclear ICBMs or our "secret" cyberwar to sabotage their death wish (Secret? As in Need to Know and Eyes Only for all readers of The Times?). No, the story is that Trump "inherits" a longstanding geopolitical game of nuclear chicken with a failed state.

Silly me but I thought people ran for office not to "inherit" problems but to confront and fix them.

Maybe Trump finally got into the heads of the headline writers at The Times and they no longer resist Trump's truth: everything is about him or is newsworthy because it reflects his magnificence. A headline isn't one if Trump isn't in it.

The world might blow up but as long as the world revolves around Trump, it's good. Intact or in pieces, it's always about Trump.

What Trump inherited was millions from his father. Not the presidency or the prospect of the end times that come with being the world's hegemon.

This is what he wanted.

If there's anything to inherit, it'll be the wind.

In the Age of Trump, the rules have changed. The Press is correctly redefining and evolving its role as Protector of Democracy and Defender of the Constitution.

The "make-up the news" proactive strategy of Fake media has been leading reality. But now the NYT is getting back on its feet and showing its grit, creativity, and brilliance, while also redeeming themselves for Bernie.

I'm reminded of the Patriots rally midway through the third quarter.

This, like other world issues, is a growing problem.

Question: If Hillary was president... would your comment be the same?

It's highly unlikely that Hillary would do half the inane things Trump has done so far, in spite of the Republican spin against her...And you definitely wouldn't see her cozying up to Vladimir Putin or the Russians
Trump's last tweet to the nation (sent from his bunker in Mar-a-Lago): "Duck and cover!"
Revisionist history, Bush did not disavow the Clinton framework until North Korea Detonated a nuclear device in 2006.
It may be the only way to get the attention of the WH.

Please. The madman approach will not work as long as N. Korea has China backing him up.

"Then, sign a non-aggression treaty with Kim Jong-un."

What if the condition for that pact is abrogation of the defense treaty with South Korea? ... That's what I thought.

The apparent unchecked #ichytwitterfinger of the commander-in-chief (drawing red lines) should make us all nervous, particularly with a military behind him that is burgoening with virgin nuclear capacity, ungratified from decades of cloistered @LosAlamosNatLab weapons development & simulations, (now under Rick Perry) encouraged by the shift from the language of deterrence to the innuendo of 'limited' nuclear war (https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/theres-no-such-thing-as-limited-.... Let's how and pray that cool heads prevail and war does not evoke the next political distraction and a manipulation into a call for unity behind the President.
Please excuse my many typographical errors.
Yeah, yeah, we'll get to the diplomacy thing right after we cut the state department by 1/3.
I find it ironic to read here that America had no compunction against using cyber tools to disrupt the workings of other counties.  Reap what you sow is so true.

These cyber tools were used to disrupt a mad-man from successfully developing nuclear weapons to attack our homeland.  Being that you live on the west coast, countering this threat should be of high importance to you.  If you are referring to the cyber attacks leveled against our election process last year, there is no equivalence.  We were not a threat to the security of the world and our neighbors.  The attack against the DNC and Clinton campaign was an attack on our democratic process to elect leaders; and as the leaks continue to show, shady financial dealings was probably a major motivation for it all.  Apples and oranges.

Iver: That North Korea is a desperate, rogue nation with a madman at the helm and thousands of pieces of artillery aimed at Seoul, plus nuclear and long-range missile capability, is not a myth or conspiracy theory. This is real.
Imagine if you will that a democrat trusts his government so much that he volunteers to go obliviously to hell, never to know why. Is there a place in democracy for that view? One disagrees, sir.
Nothing like beating the drums of war with the so-called president's fingers so close to the nuke-the-earth buttons. Way to go NYTimes.
You don't surely think the NYT is responsible for drumming up North Korea's missle insanity, do you? -- This has been going on since the 1990s, with nuclear testing starting over a decade ago.

I agree with much of what you said.  To your last few sentences - the key is convincing China.  There is tension between China and the North.  Not noted often in Western media is that the leaders of China meet with South Korea regularly - but have NOT met face to face with the new regime in the North.  That could be why Kim just assassinated his brother - who was being protected while living in China.  We know China has propped up the North over the decades because of US troops in the South.  I say - make a deal with them to get rid of Kim and the US takes out its troops from the South.  Kim probably has similar thoughts - which is why he's determined to develop his own weapons.  If he was relying on China - it wouldn't be an issue.  China has it's own arsenal that could protect him.  He knows they don't really like him.  He's paranoid.  This is a delicate game.
North Korea and cyber attacks on our electricity grid are what keep me up at night, unfortunately.

I agree - but this guy in the North is crazy..  China is their only "friend".  Yet China's President has never met with him.   That is telling.  The guy just assassinated his own brother - who was being protected by China.  I fear no diplomacy works with a mad man like that.
I think Trump is more worried about his cyberwar with Obama.
Why does the press think it's a good idea to publicize this?
Maybe trump released that so everyone understands him whining for no solution cause its such a complex thing for him ?..

Because:

1) this information is not classified.
2) it is valuable to the proper functioning of a self-governing society.
3) we are not at war with North Korea.
4) this is not a “legitimate and non-newsworthy” government secret.
5) since Trump ignores intelligence, the only way to brief him is through the press.

Uhm, it's a good idea Titian because N. Korea is an unstable nuclear power with the ability to deliver it against other countries in Asia, and on the pathway to having a thermonuclear ICBM. Add to that equation a new, untested and unpredictable (at best) U.S. Presidential Administration which will be guiding policy against this threat.

In other words, newsworthy.
